contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox settlement |official_name = Kumrovec |image_skyline = |image_caption = |image_shield = |pushpin_map = Croatia |map_caption = Location of Kumrovec in Croatia |coordinates_region = HR |subdivision_type = [[Countries of the world|Country]] |subdivision_name = [[Croatia]] |subdivision_type1 = [[Counties of Croatia|County]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Krapina-Zagorje county|Krapina-Zagorje]] |area_total_km2 = |population_as_of = 2011 |population_note = |population_total = 1593 |latd = 46 |latm = 5 |lats = 8 |latNS = N |longd = 15 |longm = 40 |longs = 40 |longEW = E |leader_title = Mayor |leader_name = Dragutin Ulama |timezone = [[Central European Time|CET]] |utc_offset = +1 |timezone_DST =[[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] |utc_offset_DST =+2 |notes = }} '''Kumrovec''' is a [[village]] in the northern part [[Croatia]], part of [[Krapina-Zagorje County]]. It sits on the [[Sutla]] River, along the Croatian-[[Slovenia]]n border. The Kumrovec municipality has 1,593 residents (2011), but the village itself has only 269 people.<ref name="Census 2011">{{Croatian Census 2011 First Results|page=34}}</ref> The municipality was established on May 6, 1997 after it was split from the municipality of [[Tuhelj]]. [[Image:Kumrovec-TitoHouse.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Birth house of Tito]] Kumrovec's claim to fame is that it is the birthplace of marshal [[Josip Broz Tito]] (1892–1980), the president of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|former Yugoslavia]]. The birth house of Tito (built in 1860 as the first brickwork house in the village) features the Memorial Museum of Marshal Tito, opened in 1953. The Museum is also important for the local folklore. Next to the house is the bronze standing statue of Marshal Tito (made by [[Antun Augustinčić]], 1948). The old part of Kumrovec comprises the Ethnological Museum with 18 village houses, displaying permanent exhibitions of artifacts related to the life and work of Zagorje peasants in the 19th/20th century. The village is small but was of great popularity in the former Yugoslavia. [[Image:Titoaugustincic.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Tito's statue in Kumrovec, made by the artist [[Antun Augustinčić]] (1900-1979)]] Today the major attraction of Kumrovec is the Ethnological Museum Staro Selo (Old Village) Kumrovec with very well preserved village houses from the turn of 19th/20th century. The reconstruction and redecoration of these houses started in 1977. So far 40-odd houses and other farm-stead facilities have been restored, which makes Staro Selo the most attractive place of this kind in Croatia. Visitors may see permanent ethnological exhibitions such as the [[Zagorje]]-style Wedding, the Life of Newly-weds, From Hemp to Linen, Blacksmith's Crafts, Cart-wright's Craft, Pottery, From Grain to Bread, etc. [[Image:Obelisk himna Zelenjak.jpg|thumb|Monument to the [[Croatian anthem]]]] On November 24, 1935 the [[Brethren of the Croatian Dragon]] raised a monument to the Croatian anthem [[Lijepa naša domovino]] to celebrate its one hundredth anniversary. Kumrovec celebrates this day as its municipal holiday.<ref>[http://www.tz-zagorje.hr/o-zupaniji/odredista/kumrovec.html Kumrovec]</ref> ==Culture== The municipality is home to the cultural organization ''KUD Kumrovec''.<ref>[http://www.hrvatskifolklor.com/php/kzzupanijafakud.php KUDovi]</ref> It has two Catholic chapels: ''Kapela sv. Rok'' built in 1963 and ''Kapela Majke Božje Snježne'' built in 1639.<ref>[http://www.zagorjepublic.com/informativni_vodie/Vodie_2005-Kumrovec.pdf Kumrovec]</ref> ==Population== According to the 2011 census, the municipality had a total population of 1,593 in ten separate settlements:<ref name="Census 2011"/> * [[Donji Škrnik]] (pop. 169) * [[Dugnjevec]] (pop. 67) * [[Kladnik]] (pop. 155) * Kumrovec (pop. 269) * [[Podgora, Krapina-Zagorje County|Podgora]] (pop. 45) * [[Ravno Brezje]] (pop. 216) * [[Razdrto Tuheljsko]] (pop. 97) * [[Razvor]] (pop. 196) * [[Risvica]] (pop. 276) * [[Velinci]] (pop. 103) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Kumrovec}} * [http://www.kumrovec.hr/ Official site] * [http://see-croatia.com/?level=album&id=22 A gallery of exhibits from the Ethnological Museum in Kumrovec] {{Krapina-Zagorje}} {{coord|46|05|08|N|15|40|40|E|region:HR_type:city|display=title}} [[Category:Populated places in Krapina-Zagorje County]] [[Category:Municipalities of Croatia]]
